Bézier splines are a mathematical curve used in computer graphics and modeling. They are widely used to create smooth curves, surfaces, and shapes. The technique involves defining a series of control points that determine the path of the curve. The curve intersects each control point, but does not pass through it unless the point coincides with another control point. In this discussion, we will analyze some programs that have implemented Bézier splines, and explore how it can be used in 3D space with WebGL and Three.js API.

One example of a program that uses Bézier splines is Adobe Illustrator. Illustrator provides a range of spline tools such as the Pen tool, Anchor point tool, and Direct Selection tool that are used to create, manipulate, and manage Bézier curves. Users can define a series of control points on a curved path, and Illustrator will generate a smooth curve that passes through these points. The curve can then be manipulated using the spline tools to create complex shapes and designs.

Another example is Blender, a 3D graphics creation application. In Blender, Bézier curves are used to create complex 3D shapes and surfaces. Users can define control points that determine the path of the curve. The curve can be extruded and beveled to create solid objects, and the control points can be manipulated to add details and complexity to the object.

We would define control points in 3D space that determine the path of the curve in the x, y, and z axes. We can then use Three.js to generate a curve object that passes through these control points and interpolate a smooth curve between them. Users can interact with the curve object using mouse controls to rotate and manipulate the control points to create complex 3D shapes and surfaces.
